bib.title: The Value Of Nu For Fission Spectrum Induced Andspontaneous Fission Of 238U

free_txt: BP
The scatterers consisted of solid cylindrical bars of
uranium metal, 3.0 cm in diameter by 35 cm long. Two
enrichments were available to us, namely natural
uranium (0.71% 235U) and slightly enriched
uranium (0.92% 235U). The dummy scatterer was
a bismuth cylinder of similar dimensions.
Corrected for inelastic scattering and delayed
neutrons, plus by extrapolating the intensity to zero
235U enrichment.
The detection system consisted of BF3,
proportional counters embedded in paraffin and placed
along two circles approximately concentric with the
axis of the beam. They were well shielded by
additional water, paraffin, boron and cadmium.
Random errors of positioning, counting
statistics and uncertainties in the size of the
systematic corrections.
The total intensity of the fast beam at the
center of the detection system was about 2*10**3 n/sec.
A beam of piled neutrons 4 cm2 emerging from the EL.2
reactor. The fast beam emerging at 90 degrees to the
thermal beam is collimated by a hole 100 cm long by
2.5 cm in diameter placed in a large tank of water.
A beam of pile neutrons 4 cm2 emerging from the
reactor strikes a 3 mm thick uranium converter plate,
enriched to 20 per cent in 235U. The fast beam
emerging at 90 degrees to the thermal beam is
collimated by a hole 100 cm long by 2.5 cm in
diameter placed in a large tank of water. Emerging
from the collimator it passes through a cavity in a
large paraffin cylinder containing the neutron
detection system. Scatterers could be inserted in
this cavity, along the beam axis.
page 104.
A small correction due to spontaneous fission in 238U
was applied to the final result. A correction for the
17 per cent fission fraction due to 235U with the
fast beam was also applied. Finally, the result has
been corrected for the degradation of the neutron
spectrum in the beam. The the value of the overall
correction for anisotropy turned out to be 2.0+-0.5%.
The detection system consisted of BF3,
proportional counters embedded in paraffin and placed
along two circles approximately concentric with the
axis of the beam. They were well shielded by
additional water, paraffin, boron and cadmium. The
fission chamber used in the coincidence measurements
consisted of 19 parallel plates of aluminum coated
on both sides (except for the end plates) with
natural uranium oxide to a nominal thickness of 1
mg/cm2. The chamber was filled with a mixture of 95%
Ar and 5% CO2, at atmospheric pressure.
Most of the experimental error is due to the
counting statistics.
The total intensity of the fast beam at the
center of the detection system was about 2*10**3 n/sec.
A beam of piled neutrons 4 cm2 emerging from the EL.2
reactor. The fast beam emerging at 90 degrees to the
thermal beam is collimated by a hole 100 cm long by
2.5 cm in diameter placed in a large tank of water.
A beam of pile neutrons 4 cm2 emerging from
the reactor strikes a 3 mm thick uranium converter
plate, enriched to 20 per cent in 235U. The fast beam
emerging at 90 degrees to the thermal beam is
collimated by a hole 100 cm long by 2.5 cm in
diameter placed in a large tank of water. Emerging
from the collimator it passes through a cavity in a
large paraffin cylinder containing the neutron
detection system. The coincidence rate between
fissions occurring in a fission chamber placed in the
beam and the secondary neutrons detected by the BF3,
counter assembly. A fission chamber using natural
uranium was used. The thermal neutron beam for
inducing fission in the 235U of the chamber was
obtained by replacing the converter plate by a
paraffin block which scattered the pile neutrons into
the collimating system. A simple mechanical
arrangement made it possible to have either the fast
beam, thermal beam or no beam.
page 105.
Calculated or measured corrections for alpha-pile-up,
stray thermal neutron induced fission in 238U,
accidental coincidences, etc., were negligible, their
combined value being under 1%.
The detection system consisted of BF3,
proportional counters embedded in paraffin and placed
along two circles approximately concentric with the
axis of the beam. They were well shielded by
additional water, paraffin, boron and cadmium. The
fission chamber used in the coincidence measurements
consisted of 19 parallel plates of aluminum coated
on both sides (except for the end plates) with
natural uranium oxide to a nominal thickness of 1
mg/cm2. The chamber was filled with a mixture of 95%
Ar and 5% CO2, at atmospheric pressure.
Most of the experimental error is due to the
counting statistics.
A beam of pile neutrons 4 cm2 emerging from
the reactor strikes a 3 mm thick uranium converter
plate, enriched to 20 per cent in 235U. The fast beam
emerging at 90 degrees to the thermal beam is
collimated by a hole 100 cm long by 2.5 cm in
diameter placed in a large tank of water. Emerging
from the collimator it passes through a cavity in a
large paraffin cylinder containing the neutron
detection system. The spontaneous fission of 238U was
easily obtained by measuring the fission and
coincidence rates in the absence of primary neutrons.
page 105.
